definition: to lay down (a rule, a plan of action)/to draw up/booked out (i.e. already fully booked)
to agree/to conclude/to draw up/to subscribe to (a newspaper etc)/to order

to go out/to come out/to occur/to produce/to go beyond/to rise/to put forth/to happen/(used after a verb to indicate an outward direction or a positive result)/classifier for dramas, plays, operas etc
variant of 出[chu1] (classifier for plays or chapters of classical novels)

sentences.english: I haven't yet made vacation plans.
When you have formed a plan, you must follow it out.
sentences.chinese: 计划订出之后，必须贯彻执行。

sentences.english: The seats in the concert are overbooked.
sentences.chinese: 音乐会的座位都已超额订出了。

sentences.english: According to mileage, a delivery charge should be worked out which I will provide all details.
sentences.chinese: 据里程，送货费用应订出，我会提供所有细节。

sentences.english: Her boss prefers her to block out her annual vacation time.
sentences.chinese: 老板要她订出每年度假的时间。

sentences.english: The committee mapped out a long-term plan.

definition: to set/to designate/to stipulate/to provide/to draw up/to formulate (rules etc)/stipulation
to determine/to fix upon/to set (a target, a price etc)
to investigate and plan forward
to stipulate/to state expressly/to explicitly provide for
to revise (text, plan etc)
to adopt (a system, policy, strategy etc)
to schedule
to arrange in order/to compile/to prepare (a budget, project etc)
to respond accordingly to/to adapt to/to cope with
variant of 計劃|计划[ji4 hua4]
to draft/to devise/to compose
to estimate
regulations
rough estimate
rule
timetable/schedule
